newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - BAA shares aim for 750p target.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - BAA shares aim for 750p target.

text.p: DAY'S RANGE * SUPPORT * RESTNCE* MA-50 * MA-200
+ Chart breakout from a long-term consolidation pattern by shares in BAA implies they can go up to 750p over the medium-term, technical analysts said.

+ Underlying volatility in the share price may produce large price swings near-term, but the price-relative chart of BAA and its 50- and 200-day moving averages indicate the overall uptrend will win through, they added.
Shares in airports management group BAA are on a rising trend that should see them go up to 750p medium-term, technical analysts said.

The share price has swung wildly after breaking above previous resistance at 545p-550p in June so that its historic 10 day volatility has shot up to 51 percent from a low of 11 percent. But this has not undermined the longer-term trend.

"A longer look at the price and relative (charts) encourages me to believe that BAA has much more potential than the 600p target I gave (originally)," said Richard Lake, technical analyst at Brewin Dolphin & Co.
"With upward breaks in both price and relative a medium-term target of 750p looks quite possible," Lake added.

A price-relativity chart -- of the share price divided by the All-Share index -- shows the share price has been gradually trending higher since May although a clear chart breakout has not occurred. By 0920 GMT, BAA shares were down 1-1/2p to 585p.

Since 1994, the shares had been shuffling sideways between 420p and 550p but started to venture higher in November 1996 and by making a series of higher lows and breaking out of a bullish ascending triangle pattern in June this year and which can be observed on a weekly chart of the share price.

An indication of a higher share price had been given in February when BAA's 50-day moving average had crossed above the 200 day average. Both averages are now following the share price up and despite near-term volatility that trend should take the shares higher, analysts said.
